p: Apples contain approximately 2.21 g/100 g of total fiber. Of that, 70% is insoluble fiber, including cellulose and hemicellulose, and 30% is soluble fiber, mainly pectin [ 78]. Pectins are complex polysaccharides present in the cell wall of higher plants, which are not metabolized in the upper digestive tract in humans [ 79]. Beneficial health effects of pectin are attributed to its ability to lower cholesterol [ 80], slow down glucose absorption, and increase colonic short-chain fatty acid (SCFAs) production [ 78, 81].
